articles.summary: The new rules, provisionally agreed by EU co-legislators, seek to reinforce support and protection measures for victims and their rights in criminal proceedings.Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant legal advancement in the EU that strengthens protections and support systems for victims of crime, including vulnerable groups and survivors of sexual violence. This update to the Victims’ Rights directive introduces concrete measures such as legal aid, faster compensation, helplines, and healthcare access including abortion rights, which have broad societal impact and improve justice and care for many people across the EU.
articles.personality_title: EU updates law to better protect and support crime victims
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) had a set of rules called the Victims’ Rights directive from 2012, which aimed to protect people who suffer from crimes. In 2023, the EU Commission proposed updating these rules to improve support and protections for victims.

**What happened** – In June 2025, EU lawmakers from the Parliament and the Council agreed on new rules that strengthen victims’ rights. These include giving victims better information and emotional support during court cases, providing legal help if they cannot afford it, and speeding up compensation payments. The new rules also create helplines accessible online and by phone across the EU, allow victims to report crimes in person or online (including those in prisons or care centers), and ensure special support for victims with particular needs, such as those facing life-threatening situations or survivors of sexual violence. Importantly, this update is the first EU law to mention abortion rights as part of healthcare for survivors of sexual violence, following each country’s laws. It also improves protections and services for child victims, making the process less stressful.

**Impact** – This update is important because it fills gaps in how victims are supported and protected. For example, victims now get quicker legal aid and compensation, which can help them recover faster. The new helplines and online reporting make it easier to reach help. Including abortion rights in the law recognizes the real needs of sexual violence survivors and sets a new standard for care. Special attention to children and vulnerable people means the law considers different needs more carefully than before.

**What’s next step** – The agreement must be officially approved by both the EU Parliament and the Council before it becomes law. Once adopted, member countries will start applying these new protections and support systems.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU has agreed on stronger laws to give crime victims better support, faster justice, and improved healthcare, including new rights for survivors of sexual violence.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’UE renforce les protections et l’aide aux victimes de crimes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne (UE) disposait d’une directive sur les droits des victimes datant de 2012, visant à protéger les personnes victimes d’infractions. En 2023, la Commission européenne a proposé de mettre à jour ces règles pour mieux soutenir et protéger les victimes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En juin 2025, les législateurs de l’UE au Parlement et au Conseil ont convenu de nouvelles règles renforçant les droits des victimes. Ces mesures comprennent une meilleure information et un soutien émotionnel lors des procès, une aide juridique pour les victimes sans ressources, et un paiement plus rapide des compensations. De plus, des lignes d’assistance seront accessibles en ligne et par téléphone dans toute l’UE, les victimes pourront signaler les crimes en personne ou en ligne (y compris celles en prison ou en centres de soins), et un soutien spécifique sera offert aux personnes en situation dangereuse ou aux survivants de violences sexuelles. Cette mise à jour est la première à mentionner le droit à l’avortement comme partie des soins de santé pour les survivants de violences sexuelles, selon la loi nationale. Elle améliore aussi la protection des enfants victimes en rendant le processus moins éprouvant.

**Impact** – Cette mise à jour comble des lacunes dans la protection et le soutien des victimes. Par exemple, l’aide juridique et les compensations plus rapides aident à une meilleure récupération. Les lignes d’assistance et le signalement en ligne facilitent l’accès à l’aide. L’inclusion du droit à l’avortement reconnaît les besoins réels des survivants de violences sexuelles et fixe un nouveau standard de soins. L’attention portée aux enfants et aux personnes vulnérables montre une meilleure prise en compte des besoins variés.

**Prochaine étape** – L’accord doit être officiellement adopté par le Parlement et le Conseil de l’UE avant d’entrer en vigueur. Une fois adopté, les pays membres appliqueront ces nouvelles protections et aides.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’UE a adopté un accord pour renforcer les droits des victimes, accélérer la justice et améliorer les soins, incluant de nouveaux droits pour les survivants de violences sexuelles.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE mejora las leyes para proteger y apoyar a víctimas de delitos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea (UE) contaba con una directiva sobre los derechos de las víctimas desde 2012, diseñada para proteger a las personas que sufren delitos. En 2023, la Comisión Europea propuso actualizar estas normas para brindar mejor apoyo y protección.

**Qué pasó** – En junio de 2025, los legisladores de la UE en el Parlamento y el Consejo llegaron a un acuerdo sobre nuevas reglas que fortalecen los derechos de las víctimas. Estas incluyen brindar mejor información y apoyo emocional durante los juicios, ayuda legal para quienes no pueden pagarla, y acelerar el pago de indemnizaciones. También se crearán líneas de ayuda accesibles en línea y por teléfono en toda la UE, se permitirá denunciar delitos en persona o en línea (incluyendo personas en prisiones o centros de cuidado), y se ofrecerá apoyo especial a quienes estén en situaciones de peligro o a sobrevivientes de violencia sexual. Por primera vez, la ley de la UE menciona el derecho al aborto como parte de la atención médica para sobrevivientes de violencia sexual, según las leyes de cada país. Además, se mejoran las protecciones y servicios para niños víctimas, haciendo el proceso menos traumático.

**Impacto** – Esta actualización es importante porque mejora la forma en que se apoya y protege a las víctimas. Por ejemplo, la ayuda legal y las indemnizaciones más rápidas pueden facilitar la recuperación. Las líneas de ayuda y la denuncia en línea facilitan el acceso a asistencia. Incluir el derecho al aborto reconoce las necesidades reales de las sobrevivientes de violencia sexual y establece un nuevo estándar de atención. La atención especial a niños y personas vulnerables muestra una consideración más cuidadosa de diferentes necesidades.

**Próximo paso** – El acuerdo debe ser aprobado oficialmente por el Parlamento y el Consejo de la UE antes de convertirse en ley. Una vez adoptado, los países miembros comenzarán a aplicar estas nuevas protecciones y sistemas de apoyo.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La UE ha acordado leyes más fuertes para brindar mejor apoyo, justicia rápida y atención médica mejorada a víctimas de delitos, incluyendo nuevos derechos para sobrevivientes de violencia sexual.

articles.title: Kids locked out of social media apps after Australia's world-first ban
articles.summary: The new law requires tech platforms to ensure that Australians aged under 16 don't hold accounts.
articles.content:
Kids locked out of social media apps after Australia's world-first ban

24 hours ago Share Save Tiffanie Turnbull Sydney Share Save

Watch: Australian teens test out social media as ban takes effect

Australia's world-first social media ban for children has taken effect, with throngs of teenagers waking up to find their accounts have gone dark. Others tell BBC they have already snuck past barriers and will continue scrolling and posting freely until they are caught. The new law means social media firms - including Meta, TikTok and YouTube - must take "reasonable steps" to ensure Australians aged under 16 don't hold accounts on their platforms. The ban, eyed with excitement by global leaders and trepidation by tech companies, was justified as necessary to protect children from harmful content and algorithms - though critics have argued blanket prohibition is neither practical nor wise.

This landmark policy has been one of Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's pet projects, and speaking to media on Wednesday he said he believed it has the power to change lives around the world. "This is a day in which my pride to be prime minister of Australia has never been greater," he said, flanked by parents and media figures who had pushed for the ban. "This is Australia showing enough is enough." "I think it will go [down] with the other great reforms that Australia has led the world on." Various governments, from the US state of Florida to the European Union, have been experimenting with limiting children's use of social media. But, along with a higher age limit of 16, Australia is the first jurisdiction to deny an exemption for parental approval in a policy like this - making its laws the world's strictest. Countries like Denmark, Malaysia, Singapore, Greece and Brazil are among those who have said they're looking at Australia as a test case. The Australian government has named 10 social media platforms as a start, including all of the most popular ones, but has also warned others it's coming for them next. Online safety regulator, Julie Inman Grant, said her agency will start checking compliance from Thursday. Parents and children won't be liable under this law, only social media firms, which face fines of up to A$49.5m ($33m, £24.5m) for serious breaches. "Tomorrow, I will issue information notices to the 10 major platforms and we will provide information to the public before Christmas on how these age restrictions are being implemented and whether, preliminarily, we see them working," she said.

There is broad agreement in Australia that social media companies are failing to shield users, particularly children, from harm on their platforms. Tasmanian student Florence Brodribb - known as Flossie - told the press she believed the ban would help kids like her grow up "healthier, safer, kinder, and more connected". "Our brains are going through one of the biggest rewiring periods of our lives... Social media is designed to take advantage of that," the 12-year-old said. "Young people deserve better than that."

BBC/Simon Atkinson Flossie is a big supporter of the ban

Polling shows the ban is wildly popular with parents, who hope it will also help reduce cyber bullying and child exploitation. But it is far less popular with children. Backed by some mental health advocates, many have argued it robs young people of connection - particularly those from LGBTQ+, neurodivergent or rural communities - and will leave them less equipped to tackle the realities of life on the web. "My closest friend would be 30km (18.6 miles) away from me... and my next closest friend is probably over 100km," 15-year-old Breanna told the BBC. "When our Snapchat is taken away, so is our communication." Experts are also worried kids are going to circumvent the ban with relative ease - either by tricking the technology that's performing the age checks, or by finding other, potentially less safe, places on the net to gather. Many critics have been advocating instead for better education and more moderation, with Sydney father-of-two Ian among them. "There's a good idea behind [the policy], but is it the right way to go about it? I'm not sure," he told the BBC.
articles.reasoning: Australia has implemented a pioneering law banning children under 16 from holding social media accounts, aiming to protect young users from harmful content and online risks. This policy has broad societal significance as it addresses child safety and mental health on a large scale, sets a global precedent, and has inspired other countries to consider similar measures. The article provides detailed context about the law, its enforcement, public reactions, and potential impacts, making it a substantive and meaningful positive development in protecting children's rights online.
articles.personality_title: Australia bans social media accounts for kids under 16 to protect their online safety
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Australia has introduced a new law that stops children under 16 from having social media accounts. This is the first time a country has made such a strict rule, aiming to protect young people from harmful content and online dangers.

**What happened** – Starting recently, big social media companies like Meta, TikTok, and YouTube must make sure kids under 16 cannot create or keep accounts. The government will check if these companies follow the law and can fine them up to 49.5 million Australian dollars if they don’t. Parents and children are not punished, only the companies.

**Impact** – This law is unique because it does not allow parents to approve their children’s accounts, making it the toughest rule of its kind worldwide. Many Australian parents support the ban, hoping it will reduce cyberbullying and protect children’s mental health. Some young people agree it will help them grow up safer, while others worry it might stop them from staying in touch with friends.

**What's next step** – The government will monitor how well social media platforms enforce the ban and share updates before Christmas. Other countries, like Denmark and Brazil, are watching Australia closely and might try similar rules if it works well.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Australia’s new law banning social media accounts for children under 16 is a world-first step to improve online safety and influence other countries’ policies.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'Australie interdit les comptes sur les réseaux sociaux aux moins de 16 ans pour protéger leur sécurité en ligne
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'Australie a adopté une nouvelle loi qui empêche les enfants de moins de 16 ans d'avoir des comptes sur les réseaux sociaux. C'est la première fois qu'un pays met en place une règle aussi stricte, visant à protéger les jeunes des contenus nuisibles et des dangers en ligne.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Depuis peu, les grandes plateformes comme Meta, TikTok et YouTube doivent s'assurer que les enfants de moins de 16 ans ne peuvent pas créer ou garder de comptes. Le gouvernement vérifiera que ces entreprises respectent la loi et pourra les sanctionner jusqu'à 49,5 millions de dollars australiens en cas de non-respect. Les parents et les enfants ne sont pas punis, seule la responsabilité revient aux entreprises.

**Impact** – Cette loi est unique car elle n'autorise pas les parents à approuver les comptes de leurs enfants, ce qui en fait la règle la plus stricte au monde. De nombreux parents australiens soutiennent cette interdiction, espérant qu'elle réduira le cyberharcèlement et protégera la santé mentale des enfants. Certains jeunes pensent que cela les aidera à grandir en sécurité, tandis que d'autres craignent que cela ne les empêche de rester en contact avec leurs amis.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement surveillera la mise en œuvre de l'interdiction par les plateformes sociales et publiera des informations avant Noël. D'autres pays, comme le Danemark et le Brésil, observent l'Australie de près et pourraient adopter des règles similaires si cela fonctionne bien.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La nouvelle loi australienne interdisant les comptes sur les réseaux sociaux aux moins de 16 ans est une première mondiale pour améliorer la sécurité en ligne et influencer les politiques d'autres pays.
articles.personality_title_es: Australia prohíbe cuentas en redes sociales para menores de 16 años para proteger su seguridad en línea
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Australia ha creado una nueva ley que impide que los niños menores de 16 años tengan cuentas en redes sociales. Es la primera vez que un país establece una norma tan estricta para proteger a los jóvenes de contenido dañino y peligros en internet.

**Qué pasó** – Desde hace poco, grandes plataformas como Meta, TikTok y YouTube deben asegurarse de que los menores de 16 años no puedan crear o mantener cuentas. El gobierno supervisará que las empresas cumplan la ley y podrá multarlas con hasta 49,5 millones de dólares australianos si no lo hacen. Los padres y niños no serán sancionados, solo las compañías.

**Impacto** – Esta ley es única porque no permite que los padres aprueben las cuentas de sus hijos, convirtiéndola en la norma más estricta del mundo. Muchos padres australianos apoyan la prohibición, esperando que reduzca el acoso cibernético y proteja la salud mental de los niños. Algunos jóvenes creen que los ayudará a crecer más seguros, mientras que otros temen perder contacto con sus amigos.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno seguirá de cerca cómo las plataformas aplican la prohibición y dará informes antes de Navidad. Otros países, como Dinamarca y Brasil, observan a Australia y podrían adoptar reglas similares si funciona bien.

**Resumen en una frase** – La nueva ley australiana que prohíbe cuentas en redes sociales para menores de 16 años es un paso pionero para mejorar la seguridad en línea e influir en políticas de otros países.

articles.title: ‘We won’t stop’: Afghan women keep businesses alive despite sweeping rights abuses
articles.summary: In Afghanistan, where sweeping restrictions have pushed most women out of public life, thousands are refusing to give up on work.
articles.content:
For many, running a small business has become the only viable path to earning an income – and a way to support other women who have lost their jobs.

With help from the UN, these entrepreneurs are keeping their livelihoods going, often in the face of intense social pressure and strict rules governing women’s movement.

“It was difficult for women to sit at home. They had to come out of their houses and learn,” says Parwin Zafar, who runs a tailoring shop in the northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif.

UNDP in Afghanistan Parwin Zafar in her tailoring shop in Mazar-i-Sharif. She currently employs 16 women.

Her business is one of the few spaces left where women can safely work and train others.

Although women are barred from jobs in government, NGOs and the UN itself, many have found ways to continue working from home or in trades traditionally associated with women.

These include textile production, food processing and carpet weaving – sectors that remain broadly accepted by both the de facto authorities and local communities.

A lifeline

“The one channel that exists for Afghan women is small businesses,” says Ms. Zafar. And the UN Development Programme (UNDP) is helping keep that channel open.

The agency has supported more than 89,000 small enterprises across Afghanistan, 91 per cent of them led by women, creating over 439,000 jobs.

“These are sectors where women have historically worked. There’s no questioning of these traditional businesses,” explains Waheeb Al Eryani, UNDP’s area manager in Mazar-i-Sharif.

UNDP in Afghanistan Shaista Hakimi in her restaurant in Mazar-i-Sharif.

But acceptance does not mean ease.

Many women still face opposition at home. For restaurant owner Shaista Hakimi, a mother of three, this has been painful and personal. Since her husband died two years ago, her father-in-law has pushed her to stop working altogether.

“He says people will laugh at us because ‘your daughter-in-law is working’,” she explains. Yet her restaurant, which serves only women, has become a vital community space – and a source of income for 18 women she now employs.

Staying afloat with UN support

Ms. Hakimi kept her business alive thanks to a UNDP loan and is now applying for a matching grant that would allow her to expand and secure safer accommodation.

“I can rent another place or building where I could live and do my work as well,” she says.

Ms. Zafar’s story mirrors her experience. When her previous business faltered, she received a subsidised UNDP loan, invested in new equipment and rebuilt her tailoring workshop. She now employs 16 women.

“Thank God, I was able to start my business again. This is how I can help more women,” she says.

Navigating strict rules

Even the most successful women entrepreneurs have little choice but to rely on male relatives. Decrees requiring women to travel with a male guardian – a mahram – severely limit their ability to deliver goods, meet customers or negotiate with suppliers.

“Women are not allowed to go places without a mahram. Especially if we want to deliver products to other provinces, we cannot do that,” Ms. Zafar explains.

To keep their businesses running, many rely on husbands, brothers or sons who can travel freely.

UNDP in Afghanistan

“They leverage their networks,” says Mr. Al Eryani. “If they cannot access the market, male relatives will sell the products or finalise deals with wholesalers.”

“Men we are related to are supportive. They try to sell our products in the community,” Ms. Zafar adds.

Resilience in the face of crisis

Access to markets and finance remains among the biggest hurdles. Only four per cent of Afghan women have access to international markets, and obtaining a loan often requires multiple guarantors – a barrier few can overcome.

Yet the entrepreneurs supported by UNDP are finding ways to persist, even as new challenges emerge.

With large numbers of Afghans recently returning from Iran and Pakistan, several women-led businesses have stepped up to offer jobs to returnees.

“With UNDP’s support, they employed 20, 30, sometimes 40 returnees per business,” says Mr. Al Eryani. “They became agents of support and contributors rather than recipients of help.”

An uncertain future

Despite their resilience, the future for Afghan businesswomen remains uncertain. With girls barred from education beyond Year 6, the next generation risks missing out on the skills needed to run a business or manage finances.

UNDP in Afghanistan Shaista’s restaurant welcomes women for on-site dining, while delivery and pick-up services are available for both men and women.

“There is a lack of access to financial education,” Ms. Zafar says. “The support we are receiving is not enough.”

For now, Afghan women entrepreneurs continue to hold their communities together – creating jobs, passing on skills and proving every day that they will not be pushed out of public life entirely. But without wider access to education and sustained international support, the space they have carved out may shrink even further.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

This represents a meaningful, real-world impact on women's economic empowerment and resilience under oppressive conditions, with broad significance for Afghan society and women's rights.
articles.personality_title: Afghan women keep businesses alive despite strict restrictions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In Afghanistan, new rules have limited what women can do outside their homes. Many have lost jobs in government and organizations, and girls cannot study past sixth grade. This has made it very hard for women to work or earn money.

**What happened** – Thousands of Afghan women are running small businesses like tailoring, carpet weaving, and food shops. With help from the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), these women get loans and training to keep their businesses open. For example, Parwin Zafar runs a tailoring shop employing 16 women, and Shaista Hakimi owns a restaurant for women, hiring 18 workers. They often rely on male family members to help with travel and selling products because women need a male guardian to move freely.

**Impact** – These businesses provide jobs to many women and even Afghan families returning from other countries. The UNDP has helped over 89,000 small businesses, mostly led by women, creating more than 439,000 jobs. This support helps women earn money, share skills, and support their communities despite social pressure and strict rules.

**What's next step** – Women entrepreneurs want more financial education and easier access to loans and markets. Without these, and with girls’ education limited, it will be harder for future generations to keep businesses going. The UN and local communities will need to continue supporting these women to help them grow and stay safe.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Afghan women are using small businesses and UN support to create jobs and keep their communities strong, even under tough restrictions and social challenges.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les femmes afghanes maintiennent leurs entreprises malgré les restrictions strictes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En Afghanistan, de nouvelles règles limitent les activités des femmes en dehors de la maison. Beaucoup ont perdu leur emploi dans le gouvernement et les organisations, et les filles ne peuvent plus étudier après la sixième année. Cela rend très difficile pour les femmes de travailler ou de gagner de l'argent.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des milliers de femmes afghanes gèrent de petites entreprises comme la couture, le tissage de tapis et les restaurants. Avec l'aide du Programme des Nations Unies pour le développement (PNUD), ces femmes reçoivent des prêts et des formations pour maintenir leurs entreprises ouvertes. Par exemple, Parwin Zafar dirige un atelier de couture employant 16 femmes, et Shaista Hakimi possède un restaurant pour femmes qui emploie 18 travailleuses. Elles comptent souvent sur des membres masculins de leur famille pour les aider à se déplacer et vendre leurs produits, car les femmes doivent être accompagnées d'un gardien masculin.

**Impact** – Ces entreprises offrent des emplois à de nombreuses femmes et même aux familles afghanes de retour d'autres pays. Le PNUD a aidé plus de 89 000 petites entreprises, principalement dirigées par des femmes, créant plus de 439 000 emplois. Ce soutien permet aux femmes de gagner de l'argent, de partager des compétences et de soutenir leurs communautés malgré la pression sociale et les règles strictes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les entrepreneures souhaitent plus d'éducation financière et un accès plus facile aux prêts et aux marchés. **Une phrase à retenir** – Les femmes afghanes utilisent les petites entreprises et le soutien de l'ONU pour créer des emplois et renforcer leurs communautés, malgré des restrictions et des défis sociaux importants.
articles.personality_title_es: Mujeres afganas mantienen sus negocios a pesar de estrictas restricciones
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Afganistán, nuevas reglas han limitado lo que las mujeres pueden hacer fuera de sus casas. Muchas han perdido trabajos en el gobierno y organizaciones, y las niñas no pueden estudiar más allá del sexto grado. Esto ha hecho muy difícil que las mujeres trabajen o ganen dinero.

**Qué pasó** – Miles de mujeres afganas están dirigiendo pequeños negocios como sastrería, tejido de alfombras y restaurantes. Con ayuda del Programa de las Naciones Unidas para el Desarrollo (PNUD), estas mujeres reciben préstamos y capacitación para mantener sus negocios abiertos. Por ejemplo, Parwin Zafar dirige un taller de costura que emplea a 16 mujeres, y Shaista Hakimi tiene un restaurante para mujeres con 18 empleadas. A menudo dependen de familiares hombres para ayudarlas a viajar y vender productos, porque las mujeres necesitan un guardián masculino para moverse libremente.

**Impacto** – Estos negocios ofrecen empleo a muchas mujeres y a familias afganas que regresan de otros países. El PNUD ha apoyado más de 89,000 pequeñas empresas, la mayoría lideradas por mujeres, creando más de 439,000 empleos. Este apoyo ayuda a las mujeres a ganar dinero, compartir habilidades y apoyar a sus comunidades a pesar de la presión social y las reglas estrictas.

**Próximo paso** – Las mujeres emprendedoras quieren más educación financiera y mejor acceso a préstamos y mercados. Sin esto, y con la educación de las niñas limitada, será más difícil para las futuras generaciones mantener sus negocios. La ONU y las comunidades locales deberán seguir apoyando a estas mujeres para que puedan crecer y estar seguras.

**Resumen en una frase** – Las mujeres afganas usan pequeños negocios y el apoyo de la ONU para crear empleos y fortalecer sus comunidades, incluso bajo duras restricciones y desafíos sociales.

articles.title: Global campaign reveals how human rights ‘are the basis of our existence’
articles.summary: To commemorate this year’s Human Rights Day, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, invited members of the public to write in their most cherished values and everyday essentials.
articles.content:
UN News asked Astrid Van Genderen Stort, OHCHR chief of external engagement and partnerships, about hers.

“My everyday essentials are my family, a sense of belonging, knowledge, safety and the freedom to speak, do and live the way I deem best,” she responded.

With the help of artificial intelligence, UN News has analysed the most popular themes based on the answers submitted by people across the world, from freedom to “enjoy nature” to “living in peace”.

Ms. Van Genderen Stort spoke to UN News about the campaign and what the responses say about the world today.

This interview has been edited for length and clarity.

UN News: What responses from the campaign stood out to you the most?

Astrid Van Genderen Stort: Every answer shows exactly how human rights are essential to our daily life. As a human rights advocate, I was particularly touched by the answers: “to be human to all beings”, the “right to live my culture” and “speaking and living without being scared”.

These statements are a testimony to the issues so many people still, or again, face around the world and the times we are in. They make me even more determined and committed to doing my work.

UN News: What do the responses say about the world we live in today?

Astrid Van Genderen Stort: Many individuals are suffering and living in very difficult circumstances. Yet what stands out to me from all the answers, is that people all around the world, whether in Afghanistan, the USA, Mexico and many other places, want the same and value the same: their basic human rights, their everyday essentials — a safe place to live, access to education, to be recognised as equal human beings, freedom to explore and enjoy.

This is the essence of our campaign: human rights are not something far-fetched, which we cannot influence; they are the basis of our existence and everyone has a role to play to ensure they are adhered to.

UN News: Many responders mentioned family, nature, and clean water. What can be done for the people who don’t get to enjoy those rights?

Astrid Van Genderen Stort: At these times of high conflict, it is imperative for us to continue to monitor, report and advocate for those whose rights are being violated. We have done so through the voice of High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk and our communications and media colleagues. Through statements, reports, stories and social media, we document and push for accountability.

UN News: Which rights in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR) have seen the most progress since the drafting of the document in 1948, and which have seen the least?

Astrid Van Genderen Stort: Overall, we have seen progress on many of the rights represented in the UDHR. Article 26 — the right to education, has seen the biggest improvement. From 1950 to 2023, the percentage of literate adults rose from 56 per cent to 87 per cent globally. To put it another way, in 1950, when the UDHR was adopted, only one in two adults worldwide could read or write. By 2023, that had jumped to nine in 10 adults globally.

The article with the least progress has been Article 15, the right to nationality. At the time of the 75th anniversary of the declaration, one in four children globally, 166 million, did not exist on paper.

UN News: Why did OHCHR decide to go with the theme “Human Rights, Our Everyday Essentials” for this year’s Human Rights Day campaign?

Astrid Van Genderen Stort: The UN human rights office has been one of the bulwarks against increasing cynicism regarding human rights marked by mis- and disinformation, insecurity and a move toward more authoritarian policies. It is in this period of turbulence and unpredictability that we saw a need not only to reaffirm the values of human rights, but to show that they remain a winning proposition for everyone, everywhere, every day. Human rights are in so many small actions and things that we take for granted. They are in the air we breathe, the food we eat, the books we are able to read. Like atoms, human rights are fundamental; they make up everything.

UN News: What is the purpose of the international day and why should people be aware of their rights?

Astrid Van Genderen Stort: UN international days serve as reminders, commemorations and celebrations. They are a chance to highlight particular issues or to remind us of events or movements that have helped to shape us. International Human Rights Day reminds us that the rights we enjoy are our own, inalienable and attainable. They can be violated if we do nothing to advocate for them. Everyone needs to know their rights, so they can claim them and ultimately defend them.

articles.personality_title: UN campaign shows human rights are part of everyday life
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Every year, the United Nations (UN) marks Human Rights Day to remind people about the rights everyone should have. This year, the UN’s human rights office, called OHCHR, ran a campaign to show how human rights are connected to everyday needs and values.

**What happened** – For the campaign, OHCHR asked people worldwide to share what they consider most important in daily life. Using artificial intelligence, the UN found common themes like freedom, safety, family, and nature. Astrid Van Genderen Stort, a leader at OHCHR, spoke about how these answers show that human rights are not just ideas but essential parts of daily living.

**Impact** – The campaign highlighted that people everywhere want the same basic rights, such as education, safety, and freedom to live as they choose. For example, since 1950, the right to education has improved a lot, with literacy rising from 56% to 87% globally. However, some rights, like the right to nationality, still face big challenges, with many children not officially recognized by any country.

**What's next step** – OHCHR will keep watching and speaking out when people’s rights are ignored, especially in places with conflict. They use reports, stories, and social media to raise awareness and push governments to act. The campaign encourages everyone to know and defend their rights every day.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN’s campaign reminds us that human rights are basic needs everyone shares and must protect in daily life.
articles.personality_title_fr: La campagne de l’ONU montre que les droits humains font partie de la vie quotidienne
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Chaque année, les Nations Unies (ONU) célèbrent la Journée des droits de l’homme pour rappeler à chacun les droits que tout le monde devrait avoir. Cette année, le bureau des droits de l’homme de l’ONU, appelé OHCHR, a lancé une campagne pour montrer que les droits humains sont liés aux besoins et valeurs de tous les jours.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Pour la campagne, l’OHCHR a demandé aux personnes du monde entier ce qu’elles considèrent le plus important dans leur vie quotidienne. Grâce à l’intelligence artificielle, l’ONU a trouvé des thèmes communs comme la liberté, la sécurité, la famille et la nature. Astrid Van Genderen Stort, responsable à l’OHCHR, a expliqué que ces réponses montrent que les droits humains ne sont pas que des idées, mais des éléments essentiels de la vie quotidienne.

**Impact** – La campagne a souligné que partout dans le monde, les gens veulent les mêmes droits de base, comme l’éducation, la sécurité et la liberté de vivre comme ils le souhaitent. Par exemple, depuis 1950, le droit à l’éducation a beaucoup progressé, avec un taux d’alphabétisation passé de 56 % à 87 % dans le monde. Cependant, certains droits, comme le droit à la nationalité, posent encore de grands défis, avec beaucoup d’enfants non reconnus officiellement par aucun pays.

**Prochaine étape** – L’OHCHR continuera de surveiller et de dénoncer les violations des droits, surtout dans les zones de conflit. Ils utilisent des rapports, des histoires et les réseaux sociaux pour sensibiliser et pousser les gouvernements à agir. La campagne encourage chacun à connaître et défendre ses droits au quotidien.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – La campagne de l’ONU rappelle que les droits humains sont des besoins essentiels que chacun partage et doit protéger chaque jour.
articles.personality_title_es: Campaña de la ONU muestra que los derechos humanos son parte de la vida diaria
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cada año, las Naciones Unidas (ONU) celebran el Día de los Derechos Humanos para recordar a las personas los derechos que todos deberían tener. Este año, la oficina de derechos humanos de la ONU, llamada OHCHR, lanzó una campaña para mostrar cómo los derechos humanos están conectados con las necesidades y valores diarios.

**Qué pasó** – Para la campaña, OHCHR pidió a personas de todo el mundo que compartieran qué consideran más importante en su vida diaria. Usando inteligencia artificial, la ONU encontró temas comunes como libertad, seguridad, familia y naturaleza. Astrid Van Genderen Stort, líder en OHCHR, habló sobre cómo estas respuestas muestran que los derechos humanos no son solo ideas, sino partes esenciales de la vida cotidiana.

**Impacto** – La campaña destacó que personas en todas partes quieren los mismos derechos básicos, como educación, seguridad y libertad para vivir como quieran. Por ejemplo, desde 1950, el derecho a la educación ha mejorado mucho, con la alfabetización aumentando del 56 % al 87 % a nivel mundial. Sin embargo, algunos derechos, como el derecho a la nacionalidad, aún enfrentan grandes desafíos, con muchos niños no reconocidos oficialmente por ningún país.

**Próximo paso** – OHCHR seguirá vigilando y denunciando cuando se ignoren los derechos de las personas, especialmente en zonas de conflicto. Usan informes, historias y redes sociales para crear conciencia y presionar a los gobiernos a actuar. La campaña anima a todos a conocer y defender sus derechos todos los días.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La campaña de la ONU nos recuerda que los derechos humanos son necesidades básicas que todos compartimos y debemos proteger en la vida diaria.
